title: Electron app Tray menu items are not narrated on Windows using Microsoft Narrator
body:
* Output of `node_modules/.bin/electron --version`: v2.0.10
* Operating System (Platform and Version): Windows 10 (version 1809)

**Expected Behavior**
Microsoft Narrator should read menu item text for Tray menu, when navigating with keyboard.

**Actual behavior**
The Tray menu can be navigated with the keyboard for accessibility, but Microsoft Narrator does not read the MenuItem text.

**To Reproduce**
1. Have Microsoft Narrator running
2. Press **Windows Key** + **B** to access tray icons
3. Press **Enter** to open the menu
4. Use the arrow keys (**Up** and **Down**) to navigate to the icon for Microsoft Teams.
5. Press **Shift** + **F10** to open the context menu for Microsoft Teams
6. Use arrow keys to navigate the Teams context menu
7. Observe using Narrator that this menu is not narrated, unlike the previous steps.

body:

title: fix: enable FixAltGraph to fix Ctrl+Alt accelerators on Windows
body:
#### Description of Change
<!--
Thank you for your Pull Request. Please provide a description above and review
the requirements below.

Contributors guide: https://github.com/electron/electron/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->
Windows treats `Ctrl+Alt` as `AltGr`, and this causes confusion when checking if an accelerator was pressed or not. There is a fix in `chromium`, but in C66 it's behind a flag, so we must enable it to use those accelerators.

This is only required on `3-0-x`. Fixes #14674.

title: setIgnoreMouseEvents({forward: true}) stops forwarding after a page reload
body:
* Output of `node_modules/.bin/electron --version`: 3.0.5
* Operating System (Platform and Version): Windows 10 x64

![Animated preview](https://image.ibb.co/jygP6V/bug.png)

**Expected Behavior**
`BrowserWindow.setIgnoreMouseEvents()` should keep working after refreshing the page with `CTRL + R`. 

**Actual behavior**
Running `browserWindow.setIgnoreMouseEvents({forward: true})` does not forward any events to the browserwindow after a refresh. 

**To Reproduce**
Clone from this [minimal example](https://gitlab.com/toon.vanvreckem/electron-setignoremouseevents-bug). 
```sh
electron index.js
```
**Code:**
```JavaScript
window.addEventListener('mousemove', function ( event ) {
  let el = event.target
  if (el.classList.contains('mouse') || el.classList.contains('window-handle')) {
    browserWindow.setIgnoreMouseEvents(false)
  } else {
    browserWindow.setIgnoreMouseEvents(true, {forward: true})
    // ^ this function stops forwarding after a refresh (CTRL+R)
  }
})
```

**Additional Information**
[implementation of setIgnoreMouseEvents](https://github.com/electron/electron/blob/3-0-x/atom/browser/native_window_views.cc#L843)
[implementation of SetForwardMouseMessages](https://github.com/electron/electron/blob/8dce40137c7c4f69acaae92bdcfc6dae74e45314/atom/browser/native_window_views_win.cc#L287)

**Use case**
Developer tools on the filesystem don't function well before a page refresh, but doing so breaks the app. This slows down development a lot.

**Guess:**
Maybe setIgnoreMouseEvents keeps working with a previous native window handle?

TouchBarPopover doesn't support TouchBarColorPicker or TouchBarPopover in items
body:
**Expected Behavior**
A `TouchBarPopover` can have a `TouchBarColorPicker` or `TouchBarPopover` in its rendered `items`.

**Actual behavior**
Any `TouchBar*` interface that 'pops over' the rendered `TouchBarPopover` will initially render for a few frames when activated, then revert to rendering the root `TouchBar` items. No errors are thrown.

**To Reproduce**
Create a `TouchBar` with the following hierarchy:

```
TouchBar
––TouchBarPopover
––––TouchBarColorPicker
```

title: Electron has lower volume than system apps
body:
Hello, I have been trying to integrate multimedia into my electron app. I have found that electron has a perceptibly lower volume than any other native system apps. Please advise on how to adjust the default volume to match. This seems to be a **known issue** of electron but I have not been able to find any solution for it.

To reproduce this issue, create a bare minimum electron app with an html video tag.
`<video autoplay src="vid.mp4"></video>`

1. Run index.html in your browser, and note the volume
2. Play the video through a native video player on your OS, and note the volume
3. Run the electron app, and note the volume

You will observe that cases 1 and 2 have consistent and normal volume, while in case 3 the volume is significantly lower. I have found this behaviour to be irrelavant to the autoplay policy of Chromium.

I am using Windows 64-bit and 64-bit electron binaries. I have tried versions 3.0.5 and 4 beta.

Further Investigation: After some trials, I have found that some media players made with electron (such as [this one](https://electronjs.org/apps/sharp-tune)) also suffer from the exact same issue.

Please recommend some solutions or workarounds, thanks

title: webview cookies are not persisted
body:

Cookies should be persisted in a webview that uses partition.

**Actual behavior**
Cookies are lost after relaunching app.

**To Reproduce**
1. Create webview with partition: `<webview partition="persist:webview"/>`
2. Sign in to GitHub to create a cookie.
3. Relaunch app.
4. When webview opens again, the cookies are lost.

title: Keyboard shortcuts on Linux with AZERTY keyboard
body:
* Output of `node_modules/.bin/electron --version`: v3.0.5
* Operating System (Platform and Version): Ubuntu 18.04
* Output of `node_modules/.bin/electron --version` on last known working Electron version (if applicable): unknown

**Expected Behavior**
All keyboard shortcuts should act the same way in all OS and keyboard layouts.

**Actual behavior**
Some keyboard shortcuts are not working under some keyboard layouts.
![image](https://i.snag.gy/cR4kg8.jpg)
(also, wrong accelerator is shown for `CmdOrCtrl+Plus`)

**To Reproduce**
```sh
$ git clone https://github.com/magne4000/electron-quick-start.git -b bug/kbd-shortcuts-linux
$ npm install
$ npm start || electron .
```
##### Keyboard layouts with which I have issues:
- French (Macintosh) keyboard layout
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1098371/47428678-48b8c380-d794-11e8-92e4-8a1136c1d88d.png)

- French keyboard layout
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1098371/47428694-579f7600-d794-11e8-8d0f-119943f0b60d.png)

**Additional Information**
Here is a matrix comparing behaviour of Chromium, Firefox and Electron which each of the 2 keyboard layouts from above.

| Shortcut | Chromium/Firefox | Electron |
| ------------- | ------------- | ------------- |
| French <kbd>Ctrl+Plus</kbd> | <kbd>Ctrl+Plus</kbd> and <kbd>Ctrl+Shift+Plus</kbd> are working | only <kbd>Ctrl+Shift+Plus</kbd> works |
| French (Macintosh) <kbd>Ctrl+Plus</kbd> | <kbd>Ctrl+Plus</kbd> and <kbd>Ctrl+Shift+Plus</kbd> are working | only <kbd>Ctrl+Shift+Plus</kbd> works |
| French <kbd>Ctrl+-</kbd> | <kbd>Ctrl+-</kbd> and <kbd>Ctrl+Shift+-</kbd> are working  | **doesn't work** |
| French (Macintosh) <kbd>Ctrl+-</kbd> | <kbd>Ctrl+-</kbd> and <kbd>Ctrl+Shift+-</kbd> are working  | only <kbd>Ctrl+-</kbd> works |
| French <kbd>Ctrl+[</kbd> | (Firefox only) <kbd>Ctrl+AltGr+[</kbd> works | **doesn't work** |
| French (Macintosh) <kbd>Ctrl+[</kbd> | unknown | unknown |
| French <kbd>Ctrl+]</kbd> | (Firefox only) <kbd>Ctrl+AltGr+[</kbd> works | **doesn't work** |
| French (Macintosh) <kbd>Ctrl+]</kbd> | unknown | unknown |

Those are non exhaustive keyboard shortcuts anomalies referenced under Ubuntu 18.04.
The 3 cells in **bold** can be considered as bugs, and others can be considered as nice to have I suppose.

title: Custom drag and drop type
body:
**Problem**
Right now, to start a file drag you call `WebContents.startDrag({ file:<path>, icon:<path> })`. This will spawn the following DataTransfer object: 
```
DataTransfer {
  dropEffect: 'none',
  effectAllowed: 'copyLink', 
  files: FileList, 
  items: DataTransferItemList, 
  types:['Files',..]
}
```
with `FileList` containing the proper file(s).

The issue is the `effectAllowed`, which when set to `'copyLink'` will not allow dragging and dropping files from the electron BrowserWindow to say Discord as they only allow dropped items with the 'move' effect from what I can see.

**Solution**
I propose allowing either changing the default from 'copyLink' to 'copyMove', OR allowing users to pass the drop effect as an argument to `WebContents.startDrag`.

**File changes**
[drag_utils_views.cc (Line 20)](https://github.com/electron/electron/blob/6f91af93433df4e9c0e7fb592e5b2dcb0b1c7888/atom/browser/ui/drag_util_views.cc#L20) - add argument for `DragFileItems` to accept a drop type (should be an int AFAIK, the [Chromium `DragOperation`s are defined here](https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/66.0.3359.158/ui/base/dragdrop/drag_drop_types.h#17)).
[drag_utils_views.cc (Line 45)](https://github.com/electron/electron/blob/6f91af93433df4e9c0e7fb592e5b2dcb0b1c7888/atom/browser/ui/drag_util_views.cc#L45) - `ui::DragDropTypes::DRAG_COPY | ui::DragDropTypes::DRAG_LINK` changed to a variable passed to the function.
[drag_utils.h (Line 18)](https://github.com/electron/electron/blob/6f91af93433df4e9c0e7fb592e5b2dcb0b1c7888/atom/browser/ui/drag_util.h#L18) - add argument for `DragFileItems` to accept a drop type.
[drag_util_mac.mm (Line 28)](https://github.com/electron/electron/blob/6f91af93433df4e9c0e7fb592e5b2dcb0b1c7888/atom/browser/ui/drag_util_mac.mm#L28) - may need to add argument to `DragFileItems` to accept a drop type too for compatibility with MACOSX. (I did not see how the drag type could be changed for osx, if they even use drag types the way windows does.)
[atom_api_web_contents.cc (Line 1736)](https://github.com/electron/electron/blob/cb9be091aa203f27496b2b8993e10b5c554525c4/atom/browser/api/atom_api_web_contents.cc#L1736) - get the drop type from `item` like
```
int item;
if (!item.Get("dropType", &item)) {
  item = <some default drop type value, like ui::DragDropTypes.DRAG_COPY | ui::DragDropTypes.DRAG_LINK as it was previously>
}
```
[atom_api_web_contents.cc (Line 1754)](https://github.com/electron/electron/blob/cb9be091aa203f27496b2b8993e10b5c554525c4/atom/browser/api/atom_api_web_contents.cc#L1754) - pass argument for drop type.


**Outcome**
Example usage of WebContents.startDrag could now be
```
contents.startDrag({
  file: 'C:/example/file.png',
  icon: 'myico.png',
  dropType: 3, // 3 for copyMove
})
```

title: Unable to select valid proxy from PAC for websocket connections
body:
* Output of `node_modules/.bin/electron --version`: 3.0.4
* Operating System (Platform and Version): Windows 10 & 7, macOS 10.13
* Output of `node_modules/.bin/electron --version` on last known working Electron version (if applicable): All of `2.x.x`

When attempting to create a websocket connection, Chrome's network stack attempts to process the pac file to find which proxy to use. It seems that we are able to read the pac file, but unable to pull the correct proxy from it. We are returned an empty string for the proxy file. What's interesting here is that the pac file can be read + resolve a proxy to use for all non websocket connections. Below is a netlog sample showing this that results in the final net_error of "net_error = -336 (ERR_NO_SUPPORTED_PROXIES)":

title: Windows support for `systemPreferences.isDarkMode()` API
body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Electron has an API which works on macOS for detecting when the system is in Dark Mode.
[Windows 10 also has a dark mode setting](https://www.digitaltrends.com/computing/how-to-enable-dark-mode-in-windows-10/). It would be useful if the same Electron API also worked on Windows.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
1. The `systemPreferences.isDarkMode()` method should work on Windows.
2. Ideally a way of subscribing to change events, equivalent to `systemPreferences.subscribeNotification('AppleInterfaceThemeChangedNotification', callback)`. Or perhaps the `color-changed` event (or another event) would be fired by `systemPreferences`.

**Additional context**
On Windows the state of the dark mode setting [is stored in the](https://stackoverflow.com/a/51336913/365069) `HKCU(HKLM)\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Themes\Personalize\AppsUseLightTheme` registry key.

title: `mksnapshot` binary for `armv7l` now works natively on `armv7l` machines, but still doesn't generate proper shapshots
body:
If you try to launch any application (Atom, for example) with `snapshot_blob.bin` which is generated by `mksnapshot` binary for `armv7l` architecture natively on `armv7l` machine it will throw an error and immediately exit:
```
#
# Fatal error in ../../v8/src/snapshot/deserializer.cc, line 79
# Check failed: magic_number_ == SerializedData::ComputeMagicNumber(external_reference_table_).
#
Illegal instruction
```
However, if you try to launch any application with `snapshot_blob.bin` which is generated by `mksnapshot` binary for `armv7l` architecture but on `amd64` machine it will be successfully launched.

I've also tried to play with arguments like `--no-use_ic` and `--arm_arch` but it still doesn't generate proper snapshots natively on `armv7l` machine.

Tested only with `mksnapshot` binary which is provided with `Electron 2.0.11`.

title: CSP header setting of sample code is incorrect
make: app.requestSingleInstanceLock() compatible with sandboxing
body:
at the moment, `app.requestSingleInstanceLock()` works by writing files/symlinks to `/tmp`. this doesn't work when running in a sandbox (like when one's app is distributed as a flatpak).

in order for it to work in a flatpak, you have to give the flatpak app access to the `/tmp` directory, which is undermining the purpose of the sandboxing.

a solution to this might be to have an option where the developer can specify the path for the files/symlinks. by adjusting that path, sandboxes can be configured to only need to share access to that path

with thanks

title: refactor: Improve accessibility of menus
body:
#### Description of Change
<!--
Thank you for your Pull Request. Please provide a description above and review
the requirements below.

Contributors guide: https://github.com/electron/electron/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

There are a couple of accessibility problems related to menus that I've found:
 - The `Windows Narrator` couldn't announce any menu items
 - The menu bar on `Windows` (and I guess `Linux` too) was not accessible by keyboard
 - #11587

The first fix was given to us by the `Chromium 69` upgrade, which allowed the `Windows Narrator` to read the menus. This is because chromium's `UIAutomation` API implementation is not yet complete, and that's what the narrator uses on `Windows` (but the implementation progressed from 68 to 69 to allow the menus to be read).

The menu bar was not accessible because we basically didn't `focus` the `View`, which in turn didn't give it keyboard events. This was done because some commands in the menu (like copy) depend on the actual content being focused, instead of the bar. I fixed this by returning the focus before the command executes. Also, focusing the menu bar was not enough, since we used a plain `View` for the bar, which didn't implement any keyboard navigation of it's items. I changed the base class to `AccessiblePaneView`, which implements that navigation (should fix #2504).

![electron-acc-1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1690458/47253178-3d8e2c80-d450-11e8-9c0f-76bf17415ecd.gif)

#11587 was caused by the fact that the tray icon's context menu was spawned without a `Widget`, since it's not necessary to have a `BrowserWindow` to have an icon in the tray. The `Widget` is important because that's what actually captures keyboard events, and the menus leech off their parent `Widgets` for those events. I added a temporary non-visual `Widget` to the menu that gets destroyed when the menu closes, which fixed the issue.

![electron-acc-2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1690458/47253182-41ba4a00-d450-11e8-9ea0-f263d99f35f7.gif)

#### Checklist
<!-- Remove items that do not apply. For completed items, change [ ] to [x]. -->

- [x] PR description included and stakeholders cc'd
- [ ] `npm test` passes
- [x] PR title follows semantic [commit guidelines](https://github.com/electron/electron/blob/master/docs/development/pull-requests.md#commit-message-guidelines)


#### Release Notes
<!-- Used to describe release notes for future release versions. Use `no-notes` to indicate no user-facing changes. -->

Notes: <!-- One-line Change Summary Here--> improved tray icon context menu and menu bar accessibility

title: Crash when closing desktop notification on Windows
body:
* Output of `node_modules/.bin/electron --version`: 3.0.4
* Operating System (Platform and Version): Windows 7, 32 & 64 bit
* Output of `node_modules/.bin/electron --version` on last known working Electron version (if applicable): 2.0.8

**Expected Behavior**
Calling .close() on a Notification object should cause the notification to no longer be shown to the user, or if it isn't shown, do nothing.

**Actual behavior**
Calling .close() on a Notification object after having displayed a notification will cause the electron process to crash with a null pointer exception.

**To Reproduce**
Clone and run https://github.com/dbkr/electron-quick-start then click the button labelled 'crash'.

Basically, show 2 notifications with the same 'tag' using `new global.Notification()`. Observe that the `onclose` handler of the first notification is called when the second is displayed. When calling `.close()` on the *second* notification (ie. the one whose `onclose` has *not* been called), electron will crash with a NPE in desktop_notification_controller.cc:374 -  `if (data_->controller)` in `DesktopNotificationController::Notification::Close()`.

**Screenshots**
None

**Additional Information**
After electron crashes, it also seems to leave an electron.exe in the background using about 20% of a core.

title: Attaching chrome file upload dialog
body:
My chrome attach file dialog box is not attached to main window.

* Output of `node_modules/.bin/electron --version`: v3.0.2
* Operating System (Platform and Version): MAC OS High Sierra 10.13.6

* Output of `node_modules/.bin/electron --version` on last known working Electron version (if applicable): v2.0.11 

### Expected behavior
Chrome file dialog box should be attached to main Window, and don't let you do interact with main window till you haven't closed or do the actions in dialog.

### Actual behavior
Chrome file dialog box opens as independent window.

### How to reproduce
 1. $ git clone https://github.com/electron/electron-quick-start
2.  $ cd electron-quick-start
3.  $ npm install

4. change index.html code to 

```
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
  <head>
    <meta charset="UTF-8">
  </head>
  <body>
    <input type="file" value="Check">
  </body>
</html>
```

5. $ npm start
6. Click "Check" button the opened file dialog window is detached independent
7. Change electron version in package.json to  "electron": "^2.0.2", do npm install and npm start
8. Clicke "Check" button and the opened file dialog is attached to main window

I recently changed my electron environment to electron 3 and electron-builder, and now I have problem with upload file dialog window. Before changing the environment the file upload dialog was attached to my mainWindow, now it is detached and I can use the program when dialog is opened, and even if I click outside the dialog fall behind of main window. I tried to use dialog feature of electron, which gives me the opportunity to attach file dialog, but it lacks performance, when I try to upload files more then 500-1000mb, I need to open them with fs.readFile or http get request and make them blob. Browser native file dialog do this for me and it works maybe 100 times faster then with fs. How can I attach native browser upload dialog to my main window?

title: Windows Tablet Mode
body: **Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.** In windows tablet mode, you may want to change your UI. There is apps that enlarge the title bar or hide the title bar buttons since they are useless (in tablet mode, every window is forced into fullscreen mode and minimizing is disabled). The is no way to detect tablet mode in electron. **Describe the solution you'd like** ~~Something like systemPreferences.tabletMode() and a `tablet-mode-changed` should be available~~ We need a BrowserWindow instance method like `window.getUserInteractionMode()` that gives us the primary input mode for a view. `window.resize` event should be sufficient to listen to changes to tablet mode. Here is more info: https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/oldnewthing/20160706-00/?p=93815 **Describe alternatives you've considered** I looked into going to the Browser API in renderer, but there is no clear way to check if a device is in tablet mode. You can basically just check if there is touch available, which is not the same. **Additional context** This is outlook hiding their title bar buttons in tablet mode.

title: feat: deprecate modules internally using `remote.require` in sandboxed renderer context
body:
#### Description of Change
The following modules are internally implemented using `remote.require` when `sandbox` is enabled:
- `require('electron').screen`
- `require('child_process')`
- `require('fs')`
- `require('os')`
- `require('path')`

Instead of being magically available in sandboxed renderers, the app should explicitly load these modules via the `remote` module (unless it is disabled via https://github.com/electron/electron/pull/13028). Alternative approach is to only use them in the main process and broker all requests from the renderer via IPC.

Making the usage explicit will also help understanding that there is performance overhead related to the `remote` module.

#### Checklist
- [x] PR description included and stakeholders cc'd
- [x] `npm test` passes
- [x] tests are [changed or added](https://github.com/electron/electron/blob/master/docs/development/testing.md)
- [x] relevant documentation is changed or added
- [x] PR title follows semantic [commit guidelines](https://github.com/electron/electron/blob/master/docs/development/pull-requests.md#commit-message-guidelines)

#### Release Notes
Notes: Deprecated modules internally using `remote.require` in sandboxed renderer context.

Now electron loads a page from local instead of web server.

title: Enable v2 sandbox on macOS
body:
Since Chromium 69, the default sandbox design has changed on macOS https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src.git/+/master/sandbox/mac/seatbelt_sandbox_design.md , we couldn't enable it at the moment https://github.com/electron/electron/commit/66623d14598bc3c382d265313f3699f1c87272ec

```
The new v2 sandbox uses system sandbox API, there does not seem to have
a way to support it in --enable-mixed-sandbox, we should probably
deprecate the API.
```

The api is still marked experimental https://github.com/electron/electron/blob/master/docs/api/app.md#appenablemixedsandbox-experimental-macos-windows , lets remove it in favor of `app.enableSandbox` and make sure an app can either be completely sandbox or not.

Also additional work that needs to be done to enable it https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=689306

/cc @zcbenz @miniak @nornagon @alexeykuzmin

title: Invalid explanations about `eval()` issues in the docs
body:
Electron's [Security Tutorial](https://github.com/electron/electron/blob/master/docs/tutorial/security.md) contains a section about [disabling `eval()`](https://github.com/electron/electron/blob/master/docs/tutorial/security.md#7-override-and-disable-eval) to prevent the application from evaluation code that is not known in advance.

The problem of this explanation is that there is another, not blockable way, to evaluate dynamic JavaScript strings:

```js
// The following statement prints: 'Hello world!' in the console
new Function([], 'console.log("Hello world!");')();
```

This makes useless this section in the doc because it is not possible at all to prevent dynamic evaluation of JavaScript (as the `Function` entity is part of the native library and all functions depend on it).

title: window.print() causes print-related files to be created in working dir
body:
* Version: v3.0.3 (reproduced on all 3.x builds for windows)
* Windows 10
* Last working version: v2.0.10

**Expected Behavior**
Additional files shouldn't be created when printing

**Actual behavior**
When calling window.print(), after sending the print job, .pdf, .emf, .json and .prn files are created 

**To Reproduce**

1. Download a prebuilt  version of electron 3.X for windows.
2. Run electron.exe (will run the default_app)
3. Ctrl+Shift+I to open debugger
4. Call window.print() from the console
5. Select a printer
6. pdf and emf file will be created in the working folder
7. Repeat steps 4 and 5, then additional pdf and emf, as well as json and prn files will be created

**Additional Information**
* This of course happens not only on the default app. So this can be reproduced with a simple electron app with electron running from node_modules, with the loaded html just calls window.print().
* Filenames are created in the following format: `<MM>_<D>_<YY>, <h>_<mm>_<ss>_<page-title>.<extension>` (e.g. `10_9_18, 2_18_10 PM_Hello World!.pdf`)

title: feat: Add app.getLocaleCountryCode() method for region detection
body:
##### Description of Change
On desktop operating systems the users can set different language and locale region. This allows the system to have en-CZ locale even through there is no czech region associated with english (the example results in English language with Czech data/number format/currency). However Chrome only presents region in locale based on system language.

This patch adds the API returning the OS region which can be then used for globalization. With the knowledge of region the applications would be able to show proper localization as any other native app.

##### Checklist
- [x] PR description included and stakeholders cc'd
- [x] relevant documentation is changed or added
- [x] PR title follows semantic [commit guidelines](https://github.com/electron/electron/blob/master/docs/development/pull-requests.md#commit-message-guidelines)

##### Release Notes
Notes: feat: provide user system´s region with app.getLocaleCountryCode()

title: Breaking change in node_headers release artifact
body:
* Output of `node_modules/.bin/electron --version`: v4.0.0-nightly.20181006
* Operating System (Platform and Version):
* Output of `node_modules/.bin/electron --version` on last known working Electron version (if applicable): v3.0.3 (and earlier)

We're having trouble compiling native code with nightly builds of Electron 4.0 due to changes in the node_headers files.

@nornagon helped me with the research and we believe [that the bug might actually be in `cmake-js`](https://github.com/cmake-js/cmake-js/blob/45f419bc78969908478fc9a624c8588a0127b40f/lib/es6/runtimePaths.js#L74-L84). While not a bug in Electron per se, I expect that this will give a bunch of people trouble, so I'm opening the issue here. I'm not sure what we should do - but we want to likely call it out as a breaking change?

https://gh-contractor-zcbenz.s3.amazonaws.com/atom-shell/dist/v4.0.0-nightly.20181006/node-v4.0.0-nightly.20181006.tar.gz
https://gh-contractor-zcbenz.s3.amazonaws.com/atom-shell/dist/v3.0.0/node-v3.0.0.tar.gz

*4.0*
```
node_headers
└── include
    └── node
        ├── libplatform
        └── uv
```

*Before 4.0*
```
node-v3.0.0
├── deps
│   ├── http_parser
│   ├── npm
│   │   └── node_modules
│   │       └── node-gyp
│   ├── uv
│   │   ├── include
│   │   ├── samples
│   │   │   └── socks5-proxy
│   │   ├── src
│   │   │   ├── unix
│   │   │   └── win
│   │   └── test
│   ├── v8
│   │   └── include
│   │       └── libplatform
│   └── zlib
│       ├── contrib
│       │   ├── blast
│       │   ├── infback9
│       │   ├── iostream
│       │   ├── iostream2
│       │   ├── iostream3
│       │   ├── minizip
│       │   └── puff
│       └── examples
└── src
    ├── inspector
    └── tracing
```

title: macOS: powerMonitor.on('shutdown') is triggered when app is being closed through Dock
body:
* Output of `node_modules/.bin/electron --version`: v3.0.3
* Operating System (Platform and Version): macOS 10.14 (18A389)

**Expected Behavior**
According to [API docs](https://electronjs.org/docs/api/power-monitor#event-shutdown-linux-macos) powerMonitor.on('shutdown') event should be triggered only when the system is about to shut down.

**Actual behavior**
powerMonitor.on('shutdown') event is triggered when I right-click in Dock on the app icon and select Quit or quit the app through the main menu.

**To Reproduce**
Here's the repo to reproduce.

```sh
$ git clone git@github.com:dsabanin/electron-quick-start.git -b master
$ npm install
$ npm start || electron .
```
